Scope and Nature of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) Audit
We have performed audits of the financial statements of U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan (the
Plan), an employee benefit plan subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974
(ERISA), as permitted by ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) (ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit). The
financial statements comprise the statements of net assets available for benefits as of December
31, 2024 and 2023, and the related statements of changes in net assets available for benefits for
the years then ended, and the related notes (collectively referred to as the “financial statements”).
Management, having determined it is permissible in the circumstances, has elected to have the
audits of the financial statements performed in accordance with ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C)
pursuant to 29 CFR 2520.103-8 of the Department of Labor’s Rules and Regulations for
Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA. As permitted by ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C), our audits
need not extend to any statements or information related to assets held for investment of the Plan
(investment information) by a bank or similar institution or insurance carrier that is regulated,
supervised, and subject to periodic examination by a state or federal agency, provided that the
statements or information regarding assets so held are prepared and certified to by the bank or
similar institution or insurance carrier in accordance with 29 CFR 2520.103-5 of the Department
of Labor’s Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA (qualified
institution).
Management has obtained certifications from a qualified institution as of December 31, 2024 and
2023, and for the years then ended, stating that the certified investment information, as described
in Note 3 to the financial statements, is complete and accurate.
Opinion
In our opinion, based on our audits and on the procedures performed as described in the Auditor’s
Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section
 the amounts and disclosures in the accompanying financial statements, other than those
agreed to or derived from the certified investment information, are presented fairly, in all

Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United
States of America (GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are
required to be independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities in accordance
with the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audits. We believe that the audit evidence we
have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C)
audit opinion.
Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for
the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and
fair presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to
fraud or error. Management’s election of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit does not affect
management’s responsibility for the financial statements.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are
conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s
ability to continue as a going concern for one year after the date that the financial statements are
available to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan
amendments, administering the Plan, and determining that the Plan’s transactions that are
presented and disclosed in the financial statements are in conformity with the Plan’s provisions,
including maintaining sufficient records with respect to each of the participants, to determine the
benefits due or which may become due to such participants.
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Except as described in the Scope and Nature of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) Audit section of
our report, our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial

1.Description of the Plan
The following description of the U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan (the “Plan”) provides only
general information. Participants should refer to the Plan’s Summary Plan Description (the “SPD”)
for a more complete description of the Plan’s provisions. The SPD can be reviewed by visiting
www.usbank.com/benefitsandrewards.
Administration and Participation
The Plan is a noncontributory, defined benefit pension plan primarily covering former employees
of U.S. Bancorp (the “Company”, the “Plan Sponsor”, and the “Plan Administrator”) and its
subsidiaries. The Company’s Benefits Administration Committee is responsible for the general
administration of and carrying out of the provisions of the Plan in accordance with the Plan’s
governing documents and applicable laws. U.S. Bank National Association (the “Trustee”) is
responsible for investment information related to the Plan and Master Trust.
Effective January 1, 2024, the U.S. Bank MUFG Pension Plan (the “MUB Plan”) was split and
merged into the Plan and the U.S. Bank Pension Plan. All inactive and certain active participants,
primarily retirement eligible employees, were merged into the Plan. All remaining active
participants were merged into the U.S. Bank Pension Plan. Approximately 65 percent and 35
percent of the MUB Plan assets were allocated to the Plan and the U.S. Bank Pension Plan,
respectively. All the assets held in the 401(h) account that were part of the MUB Plan became part
of the Plan.
Effective January 1, 2020, the Plan was established to receive a transfer of assets and liabilities for
retirees and certain Plan participants who were not actively employed on January 1, 2020, and
their respective beneficiaries and alternate payees, from the U.S. Bank Pension Plan. This resulted
in increases in both Plan assets and liabilities and decreases (by the same amount) in both assets
and liabilities for the U.S. Bank Pension Plan. The two plans have substantively identical terms,
and the spinoff did not affect any benefit amounts accrued by Plan participants. Beginning January
1, 2020, investments for all plans are held in the Master Trust for the U.S. Bank Defined Benefit
Pension Plans (the “Master Trust”). Because the Plan received accrued benefits transferred from
the U.S. Bank Pension Plan, the history of the U.S. Bank Pension Plan is relevant to both plans.
Effective January 1, 2010, the U.S Bank Pension Plan was amended such that all employees who
become eligible to participate in the U.S Bank Pension Plan will have their benefits calculated
under the U.S. Bank 2010 Cash Balance Plan, a component of the U.S Bank Pension Plan. A
hypothetical account is maintained for each participant where contributions are credited based on
age and years of service along with an interest credit. Certain eligible participants were given the
option of continuing to accrue benefits under the final average pay formula of the U.S Bank
7

U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements (continued)
Pension Plan or have their benefits frozen as of December 31, 2009 and begin earning benefits
under the cash balance formula.
Participants become 100 percent vested in the Plan after completing three years of vesting service.
Participants are credited with one year of vesting service for each calendar year in which they work
at least 1,000 hours. Participants who were actively employed at age 65 become vested at that time
regardless of the number of years of vesting service.
The Plan is subject to the provisions of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as
amended (“ERISA”), and the Internal Revenue Code (the “Code”).
Benefits Paid to Participants
The Plan offers a variety of payment options to eligible vested participants upon termination of
employment or retirement. The normal form of payment for single and married participants is a
single life annuity and a qualified 50 percent joint and survivor annuity, respectively. Monthly
benefits earned under the final average pay formula of the Plan are calculated based on the
participant’s years of credited service multiplied by a percentage of the participant’s average
compensation for the five highest consecutive calendar years out of the last ten years at the time
of termination of employment or retirement, as defined by the Plan.
Monthly benefits earned under the cash balance formula of the U.S. Bank 2010 Cash Balance Plan
on and after January 1, 2010, are calculated based on the participant’s account balance, including
pay credits and interest credits, as defined by the Plan. Participants with benefits under the 2010
cash balance formula may also elect a lump-sum payment option based on the value of their cash
balance account in lieu of a monthly benefit.
Certain participants who accrued benefits prior to January 1, 2002, continue to have a lump-sum
payment option based on the value of their pre-2002 cash balance account. Participants who have
a pre-2002 cash balance account no longer receive credits based on their years of service or
compensation but continue to receive interest credits, as defined by the Plan.
Participants attaining the normal retirement age of 65 can begin receiving monthly benefits
determined in accordance with elected payment options and plan provisions in effect at the date of
retirement as defined by the Plan. Plan participants may elect payment of early retirement benefits
at reduced rates after attaining age 55 and having earned five years of vesting service. Plan
participants with benefits under either the pre-2002 or the 2010 cash balance formula may elect
payment of early retirement benefits after earning three years of vesting service (the cash balance
benefit being payable at any age).

U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan

Death and disability benefits are available to participants and beneficiaries as defined by the Plan.
Funding Policy
The Plan uses the present value of accrued benefits method to determine its funding requirements,
as determined based on information provided by its third-party actuary. The Company’s funding
policy is to contribute amounts to the Plan sufficient to meet the minimum funding requirements
of ERISA, plus such additional amounts as the Company determines to be appropriate.
The Plan has met ERISA minimum funding requirements for 2024 and 2023.
Plan Termination
Although it has not expressed any intentions to do so, the Company has the right to terminate the
Plan at any time by action of its Board of Directors. In the event of a termination of the Plan, the
net assets of the Plan will be allocated among the participants of the Plan and their beneficiaries in
the order specified in Section 4044 of ERISA. Pension benefits under the Plan are insured by the
Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (the “PBGC”) in the event of a plan termination. Whether
all participants receive their benefits should the Plan terminate at some future time will depend on
the sufficiency, at that time, of the Plan’s net assets to provide those benefits and may also depend
on the level of benefits guaranteed by the PBGC.
2.Significant Accounting Policies
Accounting Method
The financial statements of the Plan are prepared using the accrual method of accounting under
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
Investment Valuation and Income Recognition
Investments are stated at fair value, and beginning January 1, 2020 are held in a Master Trust. See
Note 3 for a discussion of investments and Note 4 for a discussion of fair value measurements.
Dividends are recorded on the ex-dividend date.
Purchases and sales of securities are recorded on a trade-date basis. If a trade is open at the end of
the year, a receivable for securities sold but not yet settled or a payable for securities purchased
but not yet settled is reflected in the Statement of Net Assets Available for Benefits.

The change from the beginning to the end of the year in the difference between fair value and the
cost of investments is reflected in the Statement of Changes in Net Assets Available for Benefits
as net investment gain (loss) from plan interest in the Master Trust.
The net gain (loss) on sales of investments is the difference between the proceeds received and the
average cost of investments sold and is also reflected in the Statement of Changes in Net Assets
Available for Benefits in net investment gain (loss) from plan interest in the Master Trust.
Administrative Expenses
Recordkeeping, investment management, trust, consulting, audit, and other administrative fees are
paid by the Plan and are recorded as administrative expenses as incurred. Administrative expenses
related to the Master Trust are allocated to the Plan. The Company pays other administrative fees
related to the Plan.
Payment of Benefits
Benefit payments are recorded when paid.
Certain benefits due to participants are paid through annuity contracts purchased by the Plan from
various insurance companies. These payments are not included in benefits paid to participants on
the Statement of Changes in Net Assets Available for Benefits. In addition, certain other benefits
due to participants are paid by the Plan and reimbursed to the Plan through annuity contracts
purchased from various insurance companies. These payments are included in benefits paid to
participants, and the reimbursements are classified as payments received from annuity contracts
on the Statement of Changes in Net Assets Available for Benefits.
Use of Estimates
The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect
the amounts reported in the financial statements, accompanying notes and supplemental schedules.
Actual results could differ from those estimates and assumptions.
Risks and Uncertainties
The Plan’s investments are exposed to various risks, such as interest rate, market, and credit risks.
Due to the level of risk associated with certain investments and the level of uncertainty related to
changes in the value of investments, it is at least reasonably possible that changes in risks in the

3. Investments
All investment information, including the 401(h) account, disclosed in the accompanying financial
statements, including investments held at December 31, 2024 and 2023, was obtained or derived
from information supplied to the Plan Administrator and certified as complete and accurate by the
Trustee.
In establishing its investment policies and asset allocation strategies, the Company considers
expected returns and the volatility associated with different strategies. An independent consultant
performs modeling that projects numerous outcomes using a broad range of possible scenarios,
including a mix of possible rates of inflation and economic growth. Starting with current economic
information, the model bases its projections on past relationships between inflation, fixed income
rates, and equity returns, both in the United States and in foreign countries. Estimated future returns
and other actuarially determined adjustments are also considered in calculating the estimated
return on assets.
Generally, based on historical performance of the various investment asset classes, investments in
equities have outperformed other investment classes but are subject to higher volatility. In an effort
to minimize volatility, while recognizing the long-term up-side potential of investing in equities,
the Company’s Compensation and Human Resources Committee has determined that a target asset
allocation of 35 percent long duration bonds, 30 percent global equities, 10 percent real assets, 10
percent private equity funds, 5 percent domestic mid-small cap equities, 5 percent emerging
markets equities, and 5 percent hedge funds is appropriate.
Interest in Master Trust
Effective January 1, 2020, the Master Trust was established for pension plan investments. Each
participating plan has an undivided interest in the Master Trust. The Master Trust assets are
allocated among the participating plans by assigning to each plan those transactions (primarily
contributions, benefit payments, and plan-specific expenses) that can be specifically identified and
by allocating among all plans, in proportion to each plan’s beneficial interest in the Master Trust,

4.Fair Value measurements
Fair value is defined as the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a
liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an
orderly transaction between market participants on the measurement date. A fair value
measurement reflects all the assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or
liability, including assumptions about the risk inherent in a particular valuation technique, the
effect of a restriction on the sale or use of an asset and the risk of nonperformance.
The Plan groups its assets measured at fair value into a three-level hierarchy for valuation
techniques used to measure assets at fair value. This hierarchy is based on whether the valuation
inputs are observable or unobservable. These levels are:
• Level 1 – Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets. Level 1 investments include
cash and cash equivalents, U.S. government debt securities, and corporate stocks.
• Level 2 – Observable inputs other than Level 1 prices, such as quoted prices for similar
assets, quoted prices in markets that are not active, or other inputs that are observable or
can be corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the assets.
Level 2 investments include corporate and municipal debt securities, mutual funds and
other investments.
• Level 3 – Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that
are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities. Level 3 assets include financial
instruments whose values are determined using pricing models, discounted cash flow
methodologies, or similar techniques, as well as instruments for which the determination
of fair value requires significant management judgment or estimation. This category
includes various mineral oil and gas interests and comprise an insignificant portion of the
Plan’s investments.
If the Plan were to change its valuation inputs for measuring financial assets at fair value, either
due to changes in current market conditions or other factors, it may need to transfer those assets
into or out of Level 3 of the hierarchy based on the new inputs used. During the years ended
December 31, 2024 and 2023, there were no transfers of financial assets into or out of Level 3 of
the hierarchy.

5.Accumulated Plan Benefits
Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated plan benefits are those estimated future periodic payments, including lump-sum
distributions, that are attributable under the Plan’s provisions to services rendered by employees
to the valuation date. Accumulated plan benefits include benefits expected to be paid to (a) retired
or terminated employees or their beneficiaries and (b) present employees or their beneficiaries.
Benefits under the Plan are based on employees’ average compensation and years of credited
service, as defined by the Plan. In addition, certain employees have a separate benefit based on
their cash balance account. For cash balance accounts, benefits under the Plan are based on the
participant’s hypothetical account balance. Benefit payments under all circumstances – retirement,
death, disability, or termination of employment – are included to the extent they are deemed
attributable to employee service rendered up to the valuation date.
The Plan employs an independent actuary to estimate the actuarial present value of accumulated
plan benefits, which is the amount that results from applying actuarial assumptions to adjust the
accumulated plan benefits earned by the participants to reflect the time value of money
(through discounts for interest) and the probability of payment (by means of decrements such as
for death, disability, withdrawal, or retirement) between the valuation date and the expected date
of payment.
The more significant assumptions underlying the actuarial computations in the valuation as of
December 31, 2023, used to determine the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are
as follows:

6. 401(h) Account
In addition to the normal retirement benefits, the Plan includes a medical benefit component to
fund a portion of the postretirement obligations for retirees and their beneficiaries in accordance
with Section 401(h) of the Code. A separate account has been established and maintained by the
Plan for the net assets related to the medical-benefit component (“401(h) account”). In accordance
with the Code, Section 401(h), the Plan’s investments allocated to the 401(h) account may not be
used for, or diverted to, any purpose other than providing medical benefits for retirees and their
beneficiaries. The related obligations for medical benefits are not included in the Plan’s present
value of accumulated plan benefits but are reflected as obligations in the U.S. Bank
Comprehensive Welfare Benefit Plan (the “Comprehensive Welfare Plan”). Plan participants do
not contribute to the 401(h) account.
Employer contributions or qualified transfers to the 401(h) account are determined annually and
are at the discretion of the Company. There were no employer contributions or qualified transfers
to the 401(h) account for the year ended December 31, 2024.

8.Transactions with Parties in Interest
The Plan allows for transactions with certain parties who may perform services or have fiduciary
responsibilities to the Plan. Parties in interest include the Company and U.S. Bank National
Association. Transactions involving funds administered by the Trustee are considered party-in-
interest transactions. These transactions are exempt from prohibited transactions under 29 CFR
408(b) of the ERISA regulations.
The Plan invests in a First American Funds, Inc. money market mutual fund, which is managed by
the Company.
9.Tax Status
The Plan received a determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service (the “IRS”) dated July
30, 2025, stating the Plan is qualified under Section 401(a) of the Code and therefore, the related
trust is exempt from taxation. Once qualified, the Plan is required to operate in conformity with
the Code to maintain its qualified status. The Plan Administrator believes the Plan is being operated
in compliance with the applicable requirements of the Code and therefore, believes that the Plan,
is qualified and the related Master Trust is tax-exempt.
Accounting principles generally accepted in the United States require plan management to evaluate
tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize a tax liability if the Plan has taken an uncertain
position that more likely than not would not be sustained upon examination by the IRS. Plan
management has analyzed the tax positions taken by the Plan and has concluded there are no
uncertain positions taken or expected to be taken. The Plan is subject to routine audits by taxing
jurisdictions; however, there are currently no audits for any tax periods in progress.
10.Subsequent Events
Management has evaluated the impact of events that have occurred subsequent to December 31,
2024, through October 9, 2025, the date the financial statements were available for issuance. Based
on this evaluation, there were no events or transactions that occurred during the period that
materially impacted the amounts or disclosures in the financial statements of the Plan.

payments
Methods
Valuation date First day of plan year
Funding target Present value of accrued benefits as required by regulations under IRC §430.
The Traditional Unit Credit Method is used to determine the Funding Target. Under
this method, the accrued benefit is calculated based upon service, compensation
and Social Security levels as of the valuation date. The Funding Target is the
present value of the benefit. The disability accrued benefit is calculated by
projecting future cash balance amounts using hypothetical interest and pay credits
to Normal Retirement Date (with pay frozen at the valuation date) and then
prorating by a factor, with a numerator of current service and denominator of
projected service at decrement. Service for prorate purposes is accrued from
January 1, 2010, the effective date of the 2010 Cash Balance Benefit or
plan/formula entry, if later.
The plan sponsor has purchased irrevocable annuity contracts that have not been
distributed to participants and are owned by the Plan; the annuity contract and its
covered benefits are excluded for valuation purposes from both the assets and the
obligations.
Target normal Present value of benefits expected to accrue during plan year plus plan-related
cost expenses expected to be paid from plan assets during the plan year.

Actuarial value of assets Average of the fair market value of assets on the valuation date and the
two immediately preceding valuation dates, adjusted for contributions,
benefits, administrative expenses and expected earnings (with such
expected earnings limited as described in IRS Notice 2009-22). The
average asset value must be within 10% of market value, including
discounted contributions receivable discounted using the effective interest
rate for the prior plan year.
The method of computing the actuarial value of assets complies with rules
governing the calculation of such values under the Pension Protection Act
of 2006 (PPA). These rules produce smoothed values that reflect the
underlying market value of plan assets but fluctuate less than the market
value. As a result, the actuarial value of assets will be lower than the
market value in some years and greater in other years.
However, over the long term under PPA's smoothing rules, the method
has a significant bias to produce an actuarial value of assets that is below
the market value of assets.
Benefits not valued All benefits described in the Plan Provisions section of this report were
valued. WTW has reviewed the plan provisions with U.S. Bank and,
based on that review, is not aware of any significant benefits required to
be valued that were not.

prescribed by law, all of which are based on observed market data over
certain periods of time.

Schedule SB, Part V
Summary of Plan Provisions
General
The U.S. Bank Pension Plan was amended to spinoff certain participants as of January 1, 2020 to the
U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan. The plan provisions remain unchanged following the spinoff,other than
a participating employers clarification amendment made in 2022.
Effective at the end of December 31, 2023, the U.S. Bank MUFG Pension Plan was split into component
parts that were merged into the U.S. Bank Pension and Legacy Plans. In addition, the U.S. Bank MUFG
Pension Plan formula was frozen December 31, 2023 and future accruals for former U.S. Bank MUFG
Pension Plan participants are the same as the U.S. Bank Pension Plan formula effective January 1, 2024.
Covered Employees All employees not covered by the U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan
Participation Date January 1 or July 1 after the date the covered employee attains age 21
and completes one year of service with 1,000 hours.
Definitions
Vesting service One year of vesting service for each plan year that an employee
completes 1,000 hours of service (credited as of the date the employee
completes the hours).
Pension service One year of pension service for each calendar year beginning on or after
January 1, 2002 (January 1, 2003, if a prior participant in the Mercantile
Plan), during which an employee completes 1,000 hours of service.
Service is credited prior to January 1, 2002, if the employee did not
participate in a predecessor plan.
For participants accruing benefits in the U.S. Bank 2010 Cash Balance
Plan, no additional years of pension service are credited after January 1,
2010.
Points service One year of points service for each plan year that an employee
completes 1,000 hours of service (credited as of the date the employee
completes the hours).
Base pay Base pay, including shift differentials, premium pay, vacation and holiday
pay, short-term disability pay and elective deferrals. Base pay excludes
bonuses, overtime and commissions.
Total pay Wages within the meaning of Section 3401(a) of the Internal Revenue
Code.
Average earnings The average of the highest five consecutive years of pay out of the final
ten calendar year period ending with the last full calendar year prior to
termination. Calendar years prior to 2001 and calendar years in which a

Preretirement death Single participant: Lump sum payment of the present value of the
pension benefit at time of death.
Married participant: Monthly survivor benefit, plus a lump sum payment
equal to the difference between the present value of the pension benefit
at the time of death and the present value of the survivor benefit. If the
present value of the pension benefit is less than the present value of the
survivor benefit, the survivor benefit will be reduced so that the values
are equal, and no lump sum will be paid.

participant has no spouse as of the date payments begin, monthly
pension benefits, as described above, are paid in the following forms:

| U.S. Bank Cash Balance and Mercantile Part A benefits: Lump sum
| U.S. Bank 2010 Cash Balance Plan: Life annuity

and survivor annuity, a 100% joint and survivor annuity, an estate

Summary of Plan Provisions
General
The U.S. Bank Pension Plan was amended to spinoff certain participants as of January 1, 2020 to the
U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan. The plan provisions remain unchanged following the spinoff, other than
a participating employers clarification amendment made in 2022.
Effective at the end of December 31, 2023, the U.S. Bank MUFG Pension Plan was split into component
parts that were merged into the U.S. Bank Pension and Legacy Plans. In addition, the U.S. Bank MUFG
Pension Plan formula was frozen December 31, 2023 and future accruals for former U.S. Bank MUFG
Pension Plan participants are the same as the U.S. Bank Pension Plan formula effective January 1, 2024.
Covered Employees All employees not covered by the U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan
Participation Date January 1 or July 1 after the date the covered employee attains age 21
and completes one year of service with 1,000 hours.
Definitions
Vesting service One year of vesting service for each plan year that an employee
completes 1,000 hours of service (credited as of the date the employee
completes the hours).
Pension service One year of pension service for each calendar year beginning on or after
January 1, 2002 (January 1, 2003, if a prior participant in the Mercantile
Plan), during which an employee completes 1,000 hours of service.
Service is credited prior to January 1, 2002, if the employee did not
participate in a predecessor plan.
For participants accruing benefits in the U.S. Bank 2010 Cash Balance
Plan, no additional years of pension service are credited after January 1,
2010.
Points service One year of points service for each plan year that an employee
completes 1,000 hours of service (credited as of the date the employee
completes the hours).
Base pay Base pay, including shift differentials, premium pay, vacation and holiday
pay, short-term disability pay and elective deferrals. Base pay excludes
bonuses, overtime and commissions.
Total pay Wages within the meaning of Section 3401(a) of the Internal Revenue
Code.
Average earnings The average of the highest five consecutive years of pay out of the final
ten calendar year period ending with the last full calendar year prior to
termination. Calendar years prior to 2001 and calendar years in which a

Preretirement death Single participant: Lump sum payment of the present value of the
pension benefit at time of death.
Married participant: Monthly survivor benefit, plus a lump sum payment
equal to the difference between the present value of the pension benefit
at the time of death and the present value of the survivor benefit. If the
present value of the pension benefit is less than the present value of the
survivor benefit, the survivor benefit will be reduced so that the values
are equal, and no lump sum will be paid.
Other Plan Provisions
Forms of payment Preretirement death benefits are payable only as described above. If the
participant has no spouse as of the date payments begin, monthly
pension benefits, as described above, are paid in the following forms:
► Part B benefits: Life annuity
► Firstar Part A benefits: 10-year certain and life annuity
► U.S. Bank Cash Balance and Mercantile Part A benefits: Lump sum
► U.S. Bank 2010 Cash Balance Plan: Life annuity
Otherwise, benefits are paid in the form of a 50% joint and survivor
annuity option or, if the participant elects and the spouse consents,
another actuarially equivalent optional form offered by the plan. Optional
forms for Part B benefits are a 50% joint and survivor annuity, a 75% joint
and survivor annuity, a 100% joint and survivor annuity, an estate
protection survivor annuity, an estate protection life annuity or (for
married participants) a life annuity. Additionally, the U.S. Bank 2010 Cash
Balance Plan offers a lump sum option. During 2014 a limited time lump
sum “window” was offered to select terminated vested participants.
Maximum on benefits and pay All benefits and pay for any calendar year may not exceed the maximum
limitations for that year as defined in the Internal Revenue Code. The
plan provides for increasing the dollar limits automatically as such
changes become effective. Increases in the dollar limits are assumed for
determining pension cost but not for determining contributions.
Future Plan Changes
WTW is not aware of any future plan changes which are required to be reflected.
Changes in Benefits Valued Since Prior Year
There have been no changes in benefits valued since the prior year other than the addition of the former
MUFG participants into this plan.

Change in Method
The U.S. Bank MUFG Pension Plan merged into the U.S. Bank Legacy Pension Plan effective December
31, 2023. The allocation of funding balance and actuarial value of assets history for the U.S. Bank MUFG
Pension Plan was as outlined in the IRS method change application approved by the IRS on July 2, 2025
(control number 911755961). Though the merger otherwise met automatic approval criteria from
Revenue Procedure 2017-56, the IRS did not agree, and a funding method change application was filed
on August 27, 2025 illustrating the combination of funding balance and actuarial value of assets history
for the two plans.
